reviewText: There was 1 fighting scene at the end which was good but most of it was gratuitously mindless and unnecessary...the censored deletions made this more of a mindless montage or collage of violent scenes. A lot of ethnic hatred .i.e Japanese vs Indonesian is induced to lure mindless people to this gore fest. It really lacks the martial arts skill of directing eg Enter the Dragon, and just throws a lot of grotesque and bloody fights together.Some viewers said it was the best action movie ever...well, if you think over dosing on amphetamine is good, maybe. It really lacks restraint, and even out does Tarantino's "Kill Bill pt 2 ". Some people find mindless violence entertaining....if so, this movie is custom-made for those people...

reviewText: The Raid 2: Berandal (2014) (Indonesian Action).Viewed on March 28th at the Regal E-Walk cinema in the heart of New York City.After surviving the apartment building raid, Iko Uwais goes undercover to take down an Indonesian crime syndicate that is feuding with an invasive Japanese yakuza clan in Jakarta. Things get out of control and everything goes to hell. That's the plot in a nutshell.The fighting is the main draw of this film. Martial arts films are frequently under-appreciated because critics tend to downplay the artistry of orchestrating a fight sequence. In some ways it's like staging a complex dance with extremely difficult performances by physical talents who have spent their entire lives perfecting their craft. In many cases it can be even more challenging than executing a good dramatic moment. With that said, "The Raid 2" is an exquisite ballet of death with an incredible variety of expertly crafted action sequences that have a grounded, realistic feel to them. It's hard to describe, but despite the insane action there's very little outrageousness present. The choreography here is some of the best ever put on film.There is no question that Uwais is currently the premiere martial arts star, and there is certainly no question that Gareth Evans is the greatest action director on the planet. This man is a genius in terms of visually expressing action through vivid, mind-blowing camera-work. This guy never directed a car chase sequence in his life, and yet his very first attempt is impressive. I did notice a bit more shaky cam in this film when compared to its predecessor, but one can see everything so it's not a problem. Evans is also a pro to create a crescendo of action where every fight seems to outdo the one before it. This generates an absolutely thrilling final hour that will go down in history.The gory violence of "The Raid 2" is a big "screw you" to PG-13 action movies. Some critics are already whining about the graphic bloodletting, but these are the same guys who hand out 90% approval ratings to movies with incompetent action and no edge – *cough* "The Hunger Games 2: Catching Fire" (2013) *cough*. The gore in "The Raid 2" isn't just randomly thrown in either. It's a logical consequence of the situation and characters, and it is applied in very creative ways. I have heard that Evans was only coerced to cut a few "frames" due to the MPAA review, but I have no idea which frames those were because the now infamous shotgun kill is present in its full, unadulterated glory.The $4.5 million budget is an even bigger "screw you" to mega budget Hollywood blockbusters. "The Raid 2" has more thrilling action than every $100+ million superhero movie I've ever seen . . . at less than 4.5% of the cost. It's almost unbelievable what these guys can do with a limited budget.Given the exceptional quality of the action, the 148-minute runtime puts some pressure on the story to maintain its momentum between the violence. The first "Raid" received much criticism that asserted a generic story and undeveloped characters, but I felt that it nevertheless established a "feel" for the characters without the need for long-winded exposition. That "feel" can add quite a bit to an action film. "The Raid 2" spends more time setting up its premise, which results in some genuine plot and character development. It attempts to do this by taking a generic gangster template and infusing it with a sprawling crime saga that implements many characters. This is essentially a "chess board" setup where numerous pieces are first put into place, allowing for many possible confrontations. The viewer is therefore able to relish the moment when a particular piece attacks and takes down another, revealing the actual outcome amidst the countless possibilities.I suppose it helps to already be a fan of the actors and actresses here, since there are a number of familiar faces from both Indonesian and Japanese film industries. Needless to say, the performances are top notch. The Japanese actors have their little moments, but they could have been given more to do in this. Maybe "The Raid 3" will give them more time in the spotlight.Overall, "The Raid 2" is a very satisfying action film that justifies its hype after just one viewing. It's simply spectacular.
summary: The most highly anticipated film of my life, and it actually met those expectations
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Raid 2 is nothing like its predecessor. Whereas The Raid: Redemption is a perfectly streamlined action flick that gains momentum as it moves along, The Raid 2 ricochets between a multilayered narrative and endless waves of mobs that are thrown at our increasingly improbable protagonist. After a while, the over-stylized fight sequences render the undercover cop plot line obsolete in such a way that The Raid 2 begins to resemble a latter-day Tony Jaa picture.The infinite fight scenes are on point, as redundant as the underlying story may be. Besides, who reads a girl rag for the articles? Unlike The Raid: Redemption, which pits Rama against a locked down apartment building in a floor-by-floor brawler, The Raid 2 sends Rama to prison and back, in order to infiltrate a violent Indonesian crime syndicate. In the cooler, Rama uses his fight savvy to gain the trust of a ruthless crime lord's son, so he can join their ranks after serving his staged prison term. Once back on the streets, Uco (Arifin Putra) introduces Rama (alias "Yuda") to his father Bangun (Tio Pakusadewo), a bloodthirsty mob boss who runs a criminal racket in Jakarta. Rama is quick to prove his loyalty and becomes their top foot soldier.None of the fights feature wires. Iko Uwais's fighting style is Silat, which is the native martial art of Indonesia. As Rama takes on one meat shield after another in The Raid 2, you will see hints of Muay Thai and Kung Fu, as well as incredible weapon battles (both melee and firearm). If you have seen the preview, the scene that has Rama training on a chalk outline of a man scrawled onto the wall of his prison cell sets the tone for the entire movie. With each strike, the character builds speed, focus, and power, as he pummels a large hole into the side his cement housing. Moving forward, Rama's battles become increasingly longer, chaotic, and numerous in the amount of enemies that he must face in any given encounter. The body count rivals early John Woo.The story itself is The Raid 2's main weakness. There is just so much going on that the prospect of Rama's role as an undercover mob informant is eclipsed by the extreme violence. The little drama that does take place feels forced, as if the director included these scenes in order to provide viewers a break in the action. Other than Uco, and the surprise return of a top villain from The Raid: Redemption, I could have cared less about the characters. Instead, I found myself holding my breath during the extreme chaos and bloodshed that's somewhat spotty until the final act. Again, The Raid 2 is reminiscent of many martial arts classics that came before it, and provides a perfect synthesis of sloppy mob rumbles, weapon wielding, and Gun Fu.Director Gareth Evans has already stated that a 3rd sequel is in the works. Supposedly, The Raid 3 will take place 2 hours before the end of The Raid 2. Whatever Gareth has planned for Rama, I can only hope that the 3rd entry will feature a more cohesive story, or no story at all as in The Raid: Redemption. Overall, The Raid 2 is an excellent continuation of the series, and is required viewing for modern martial arts movie fans >>> 4.5 Stars.
summary: Excellent Follow-Up to The Raid: Redemption

reviewText: First off, some background. Read all the internet hype on the first Raid. Little plot, balls to the wall action. Loved the trailer. Don't get me wrong, I love a good story, but got it out of the Redbox with zero expectations. I was blown away. Nitpickers can nitpick away, but it was a solid, tight 90 minutes of action that gave me more plot than expected. I bought it on Blu-Ray within the week just for a friend to watch it.I was immediately hooked. I hadn't been this excited since discovering the films of John Woo in high school. I was suddenly a hooked fanboy, a feeling I hadn't had since almost every asian director came to America and the films were lackluster. So that set the bar high knowing that Raid 2 was in production.All the buzz, the hype. It's 2 1/2 hours long? I'm the type of movie goer who will sit in the theater as long as the director can tell me an interesting story. Most 2+ hour films are wanna be epics that could easily shave 45 min off the running time. Then the early buzz...the clips...the deleted gang war scene. Thats what they cut out of the film? That scene is better than most action scenes I've seen in decades.Was this going to live up to my own hype? Tried hard to not get too worked up and prepared for disappointment...it happens.This film blew me away, and Gareth Evans should be an action director for the ages. It was 2 1/2 hours. I wanted more. A large scale sprawling crime saga reminicent of Heat or The Dark Knight, but with the showcase of Pecak Silat at the core.Again, the nitpickers are there. Mostly about a few unfleshed out characters, but to me it didn't matter. Cinematography, choreography, editing? This film was a thrilling spectacle at all times, especially to a former film student with a love of action films.I saw this film with my friend and we will randomly say how solid it was. I cannot wait until it arrives tomorrow.

reviewText: Somewhere Tony Jaa is hearing footsteps coming up fast behind him. Fact is, I don't think it's premature to crown Iko Uwais as today's preeminent onscreen martial artist, and this bit of brag based only on two movies (no, I'm not counting Merantau). The Raid: Redemption (2011) was a gamechanger. It made the other action films go home to weep into their momma's apron. The Raid 2: Berandal sequels it up and, as expected, it's a bigger, more ambitious venture. It's not as good. The knock isn't against the action scenes which are exceptional stuff and match up well against those in the first movie. One gripe is that The Raid 2 runs 148 minutes long. Welsh director Gareth Evans is perhaps today's best action director. Here, he channels his inner Scorsese. He infuses his bloated narrative with sprawling gangster drama. Some of it works. But some of it is filler material, expository stop-gaps that mark time until the next pulverizing fighty fight. When the participants aren't engaged in murderous motion, the film sometimes drags.Poor rookie cop Rama (Uwais), him what just survived breaching a tenement populated with homicidal tenants. What's that phrase? "Just when I think I'm out, they pull me back in!" The Raid 2 picks up directly from the closing events of the first film as a superior officer convinces Rama to dive right back into the rabbit hole. If The Raid: Redemption is about battling for a block, The Raid 2 is about securing a city. Jakarta, Indonesia is infested with widespread police corruption. Rama reluctantly agrees to do his part, to infiltrate one of the powerful crime families so as to identify who's dirty in the constabulary. A crucial step is landing in prison so he can cozy up to the local kingpin's incarcerated son Uco (Arifin Putra, looking eerily like Brandon Lee). Rama is briefed that he should only be in prison some months. Heh.Despite strong echoes of Donnie Brasco and Infernal Affairs, The Raid 2 is best served when hordes of thugs are aiming to put a hurt on Rama and our guy reciprocates by educating them on the glory and brutality of silat. Iko Uwais' character is a pit bull, son. What separates him from other celluloid asskickers is that Uwais actually has it in him to act like the blows he absorbs actually hurt him. All credit to Gareth Evans, Iko, and the rest for translating the pain and brutality so effectively to the screen. I don't have it in me to express just how raw and creative and badass the action sequences are. Evans, gifted with an impeccable visual sense of timing, captures Iko's discipline of silat in all its expressiveness and fluidity and pure batshi+ crazy awesomeness. There are six or seven extended fighty fights that'll have you marveling and maybe instinctively dodging in your seat when the arterial spray and the ripped-out viscera come hurtling. My three favorites: the melee at the prison bathroom stall (after which Rama says, "With all due respect, I don't really like acting tough in toilets."); Rama's hallway scrap with the hot but lethal Hammer Girl (Julie Estelle) and the weird Baseball Bat Brawler (Very Tri Yulisman); and Rama's machismo-drenched kitchen showdown with the hand sickle-wielding assassin (Cecep Arif Rahman, internationally renowned silat practitioner). Meanwhile, Evans stages an electrifying car chase that, in my opinion, edges out the car chase in Captain America: The Winter Soldier. There's a moment during this car chase in which Evans treats us to an amazing overhead perspective - as if the car roof was removed - of Rama's backseat battle with his four captors. The Raid 2 is an action masterpiece, don't even argue. It's some next-level ish. And to hold down its arthouse creds, it even has moments when it works as a suspenseful crime drama. Extraneous plot threads aside.Parting random thoughts/observations:- It's surprisingly a solidly acted film; Iwo Ukais holds his own with the thespian bits- Was it a vanity play for supporting actor Yayan Ruhian ("Mad Dog" in The Raid: Redemption) that compelled Evans to insert him in a needless sub-plot? Yayan plays "Prakoso," a side character whose brief arc only obliquely impacts Rama's narrative yet is given two action sequences- I'm kind of judging Rama for his lame tactic of throwing empty water bottles at the bad guys- Maybe Rama could just bring a gun next time
summary: "With all due respect, I don't really like acting tough in toilets."

reviewText: With THE RAID: REDEMPTION, director Gareth Evans gave us an instant martial arts/action classic that would set a new standard for hard-hitting, hard-R action films. It was a simple enough plot: An elite Indonesian police unit is sent to take in a crime lord who runs his own apartment building, and the cops, led by star Iko Uwais, have to fight the buildings' criminal occupants floor-by-floor. Now, aside from this being a great action film, this unfortunately led to unfair and inaccurate comparisons to the equally good DREDD, which had a similar plot but was actually filmed before this film began production and only garnered cries of "rip-off" since it was released after this film. But that's beside the point. THE RAID: REDEMPTION is still a genius work of action cinema.Evans, however, wasn't satisfied with this. He wanted to make a second film that topped the first one, taking it out of the claustrophobic apartments and putting it in a number of different settings, and this led to THE RAID 2: BERANDAL (the subtitle being cut for the American cut), which not only tops the original in scope, but also in story and sheer brutality. Once again, we follow Rama (Uwais), as the film opens almost immediately after the ending of the first film, as he is enlisted by a secretive division within the police force to help root out even more corruption within the police department. His assignment is to be placed in prison to gain the trust of the son of one of the city's most ruthless crime lords, so that upon his release, he can lead the police to the most corrupt of the police force. If Rama doesn't do this, it puts his family in danger. He reluctantly agrees, and suddenly, he's in prison. Once he does gain the confidence of the son, after saving his life, he finds himself exactly where he's supposed to be, but not knowing who to trust. And as the tension mounts, Rama must take it upon himself to punish the criminals that the police won't touch.Without a doubt, THE RAID 2 is the most bone-crushing, insanely and hilariously brutal, and masterfully executed martial arts action film in years. Each sequence tops the one previous. From the opening fight in the prison bathroom to the subsequent fight in the mud-caked prison yard to a single assassin's nightclub fight against increasingly impossible odds to an insane car chase sequence leading to the ultimate showdown in the main villain's lair... it just keeps getting more and more intense, more and more bloody and more and more over-the-top. Uwais proves himself once again as an incredibly capable leading man as well as a genius fight choreographer. It's a long film, but Evans, as writer/editor/director, doesn't waste a frame. Some of the shots of this film are as beautiful and stunning as anything you'd see from many of his current peers. The film also gives a powerful sense of drama mixed in with the action.I would say that the only flaw of this film is that there isn't much humor in the dialogue, but the humor actually comes out of the sheer audacity of the fight scenes. There are moments where your jaw will drop to the floor from the sheer shock of what you're watching. For example, in the car chase, a motorcyclist assassin comes up against one of the anti-heroes of the film, and the anti-hero grabs his arm, sticks a fully automatic machine pistol against his helmet, and practically empties the clip into the cyclist's face. Now, if that's a moment that you might think is just too brutal, then this is CLEARLY not a good pick for you. Personally, I laughed hysterically at the sheer ludicrous nature of a moment like that. The whole film exists in a reality that is suited to the film's style and not in a "realistic" setting, giving the film a almost dreamlike quality that is breathtaking to behold.Now, if there's a cut of this film that exists that is different than what I saw that is "uncut", I'd really like to see exactly how deep the cuts were and why so many have given the release of this film in this form such a negative review and how much it might enhance the film, or if it's just a purist complaint.Regardless of how this film might be edited to garner an R rating, it's clear that no matter what, THE RAID 2 is a brilliant action film that never seems to relent, and actually tops the original.
summary: Edited or Unedited, THE RAID 2 is still a masterwork of Action/Martial Arts Cinema.

reviewText: There has been quite an uproar regarding the fact that the U.S. is getting the R rated theatrical cut of "The Raid 2" rather than the unrated director's cut  on blu-ray as some cuts had to be made to avoid an NC-17 rating by the MPAA. While normally I would also be protesting this decision by Sony, it has to be noted that the director & writer Gareth Evans stated he only had to cut a small amount of frames totalling only 4 seconds of footage. People who have seen both cuts have said that the trims are not noticeable at all. I'm not sure why Sony decided against an unrated cut but if something like 2 minutes had been cut out of the film instead, I would be furious. Considering the director was worried that the MPAA would have a heart attack watching the movie and butcher it, only 4 seconds of trims for the R rating should be considered a victory for the filmmakers. However, I would like to ask the MPAA how only 4 seconds of trims is the difference between an R rating and a NC-17 but whatever.....regardless, this is the most violent R rated film to date.As for the the film itself, much like the original, The Raid 2 is an action fan's wet dream. Brutal, epic and jaw droppingly violent,  it is that rare sequel that expands on but also improves on the original. Everything in this film is bigger and at 2 hours 30 minutes, it somehow manages to never drag and keeps escalating in terms of the action set pieces. The acting is rock solid and this film much like the original makes almost every other action film of the last decade look positively anemic and G rated by comparison. It's truly a pure shot of cinematic adrenaline!The blu-ray is loaded with all kinds of cool extras and the picture and audio quality is off the charts. Like I mentioned, don't let the lack of an unrated cut keep you from watching this incredible action film!
summary: Don't let the lack of an unrated cut deter you from watching this truly amazing film!

reviewText: If you were one of the many people to see the film THE RAID: REDEMPTION then you'll have some idea of what to expect with the sequel out this week on DVD. If you haven't seen the first film you can do fine with this one but you'll deprive yourself of the set up for what happens here. You'll also be short changing yourself if you're a fan of action films. Both films are tremendous. I would place the both in the top five action movies ever made. This is coming from someone who has seen ENTER THE DRAGON in the double digits too. Ignore the fact that the films were made in Indonesia by a Welsh director. Ignore the fact that they have subtitles (this new one does offer a dubbed version). Just rush to see these movies.The first film focused on an elite team of 20 special ops police officers raiding a 30 story apartment building housing the criminals who have paid the top crime lord for protection. This crime lord lives on the top floor of that building. Before the team can get to him they're discovered and the crime lord lets it be known that anyone who can take out the team will be granted a life time stay in the building. Now the team is fighting for their lives against a building full of criminals.THE RAID 2 picks up just hours after the first film. Hero Rama (Iko Uwais) has turned over audio tapes to the only policeman he trusts that will show a connection between the underworld and higher ups in the police force. But he's told it is just hearsay and it will take more. He is recruited to go undercover to get the proof they need to put down those who are deconstructing the police force. With his family put into protective custody Rama beats up a politician's son and is sent to prison. He's done this to get close to Uco, the son of the main crime lord now in charge. It's more than he bargained for, facing 3 years in prison to get the bad guy but he follows through.While in prison he first ignores Uco. When a riot breaks out in the rain soaked mud drenched prison yard as a cover for Uco's assassination, Rama is the main person standing between the man he is pursuing and those who would have him dead. This is just the first of 19 various fight sequences in the film and is amazing to watch. The choreography used here, and in subsequent fights, rivals the most difficult ballet ever staged.When he's finally released from prison, Rama is taken in by Uco and his father and given a position in their organization. He basically rides shotgun for Uco, giving him protection and becoming his enforcer. With each passing day he gets more and more information that he can use. At the same time he misses the fact that Uco and his father are not seeing things eye to eye. A rival named Bejo is trying to wedge his way into their organization. Using Uco as his pawn, he does all he can to bring down Uco's father and install Uco by starting a war with the Japanese crime organization.If you've seen the first film you already recognize that there is more story going on here than in that film. This is not to say that it leaves the film lacking when it comes to action though. Characters like Baseball Bat Boy and Hammer Girl live up to their monikers when it comes to combat. And a final battle between Rama and his main combative rival takes place the grip you'll place on the edge of your seat might leave indentations. The story does move along from this and the film does have an ending but I won't give any more away.While the violence in this film slides down to the extreme end of the scale it's unlike any action film ever seen. This is not the brightly colored blood spatter seen in classic kung fu movies nor is it the slow moving hand to hand combat seen in most David Carradine films. The gore here isn't put in just for the sake of gore but it's the natural consequence of actions taking place. Trust me when I say that a claw hammer is going to get messy when used as a weapon.If you think you've witnessed some of the fastest martial arts sequences ever by seeing most Bruce Lee or Jackie Chan films you have another thing coming. How numerous stunt people were not killed just in the fight sequences is beyond belief. When you watch the extras and learn about the work the camera crew did that put themselves in danger it's a wonder anyone survived this film. And yet each and every bit of effort made in this movie shows on the screen. I said earlier both movies belong in the top five action films of all time. Know up front that they belong closer to the top than the bottom.Don't hem haw around denying yourself the pleasure of this great action flick because it's in a foreign language. If you must, use the dubbing. But by all means make your way to a rental outlet or store and get a copy of this one. For myself I have no doubt that I'll be watching both multiple times. I'm betting you will as well.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Theatrical review.  There may be spoilers.In my review of the original "The Raid: Redemption" I noted "guaranteed to satisfy those who enjoy a good knuckle crunching, knife slashing, body tossing, blood spurting adrenalin rush."  In "2" director and writer Gareth Evans doubles down on that statement.The film picks up shortly after the first one ends.  Our hero, rookie cop Rama (Iko Uwais), somehow survived being trapped in a Jakarta apartment building.  Hoping to go home to his family he is coerced by the head of a police special unit to go undercover.  Refusing, he is reminded that he and his family are still in jeopardy because the real crime lords are still operating.  He reluctantly agrees on the condition that his wife and son will be protected forever.Rama is put in prison in order to get close to Ucok (Arifin Putra) who is the son of one of the two crime lords running the district.  Evans takes his time up to this point with some excellent non-violent scenes mostly showing some quiet emotion from Uwais.  Prison changes the pace and this is where the action begins.  In a mud and blood splatter sequence, the inmates battle each other and the guards which gives Rama a chance to save Ucok's life.  This is but a warm-up for what is to come of course.Upon his release, Rama is befriended by Ucok and his father and joins the mob as planned.  In an age old plot, the young wannabees of the two gangs have their own secret meeting and conspire to start a gang war between the two sides in order to elevate their stature.  The film really isn't about the storyline however, it is about the almost ballet-like choreography and athletic skills of Uwais and countless others, including Pencak Silat master Yayan Ruhian who returns as Prakoso from the first film.  A couple new killers come to the new film and should be noted.  Hammer Girl (Julie Estelle) and Baseball Bat Man (Very Tri Yulisman) bring their unique fighting skills to the slaughter.As earlier implied, this film isn't for the weak of heart or of stomach.  In addition to guns of various caliber and knives, the cast use a variety of household and workplace items in their fighting.  It's all very cool.  Speaking of guns.  Although not unique to this film, it appears that guns are never to be used when hordes of unarmed men in martial arts attack mode are available.  Why not just shoot the hero?  He can't dodge a bullet.  Logic aside, "The Raid 2" is an exciting heart-pumping thriller leading up to a hand-to-hand combat battle for the ages between Rama and the top gangster's bodyguard.  It is as good as anything I've ever seen on film.
summary: Fight sequences are as good as anything you will see on film

reviewText: After raving over THE RAID  when I  first saw the film,I was very keen to see the sequel..  What a  huge disappointment it was  for me.  Very  over long  at 2 1/2  hours. Most of the action sequences  went on for far too long and should have been  shortened in the editing room. Unfortunately I saw a  dubbed  dvd version and the dubbing was  a disaster. The actors  sounded like they were  just reading from a script rather than acting out  the  dialogue. I was  pre-warned  before I saw  the film,that it  did  not live up to the first  film.The action sequences became  so monotonous as they were both repetitive and overlong. A 90 minute film,with tighter editing  would have made this film a winner. Some of the  violence  looked  bad as  many of the actors  actually missed their victim, yet  the  person  acted as though they were  hit on their body. One had to laugh at this. .Bad editing!
summary: What a huge disappointment it was for me

reviewText: The sequel to the well-received THE RAID: REDEMPTION, THE RAID 2 is one of the rare sequels that surpasses the original in every department. The story, unlike its predecessor is grand in size and scope. Instead of being confined to a single location, Iko Uwais' Rama is sent undercover to ferret out corrupt cops who are being paid off by the gangsters who run the city. To do this, he gets sent to prison where he befriends the son of an Indonesian crime lord in order to get close to the family. Once he gets out, the story really takes off and you get an epic tale that recalls elements of THE GODFATHER and THE DEPARTED. You also get even more of the incredible fight scenes and over-the-top violence that made the first one so good. If there's one complaint I have, it's that the movie does bite off a little more than it can chew, though it doesn't lack for ambition. I did like the attempt to give some characters more depth, like Prakoso (Mad Dog, from the first RAID). Still, I would assume that most people come to these types of movies for the martial arts on display, and this one sure doesn't disappoint in that area. There's so many action sequences, I think I lost count and the good thing is that they don't really run together. Each one has a distinct quality or setting or something that sets it apart from the others. The standouts were a prison brawl towards the beginning, one that expertly cuts across three different locations, a riveting car chase and the final fight. The one that cuts across three locations also features two of the most interesting characters in the film: a guy whose weapon of choice is a baseball bat (and ball), and a deaf (and mostly blind) woman who wields two hammers. I'll give them extra points for creativity there. The cinematography and fight choreography was also improved from the last film, and Gareth Evans really showed his talent for exquisitely composed images, fluid camerawork and comprehensibility in the action scenes. The score also enhanced the visuals by adding tension, but there were also moments of quiet which were just as effective. Overall, THE RAID 2 is a considerable improvement over the first, even if the story does lag in parts. However, the action keeps things moving along at a nice clip and you won't feel like you've just watched a two and a half hour movie. One of the year's best so far, and one of the best modern action films period.
summary: A brutal and balletic martial arts epic

reviewText: This is a fantastic sequel to one of the coolest and bloodiest boldest action movies of recent years, the raid blew us away with its amazing hyper active fast paced fighting and good bloody gory carnage, the raid 2 does it again on higher level, its 150 minute running time swoops by with ease and great pace as the sequel plays out perfect with a better deeper story and much, much more amazing fighting and the bloodiest goriest action ever! The fight scenes in this are incredibly realistic and super fast, bone crunching and violent as hell, there is some incredible fights with guns, baseball bats, hammers, knives, machetes, all incredible painful and gory but beautifully done at the same time, the effects are top notch too, the fight scene towards the end of the film in the kitchen is one of the most amazing fights ever seen and is such a stand out moment in the film, there is a fantastically shot car chase action scene too which is clipped together incredibly well with great camera shots, its an amazing film overall and there's nothing bad to say, if this is your type of movie then its a total must see, easily one of the best films of the year and one of the best action movies for many years, believe the hype it raises the bar for what action in movies can be like if done by such quality filmmakers as these

reviewText: I must admit that upon first walking out of the theatre after Berandal finished, I was impressed but also a little disappointed with the results. Any fan of the original should understand right away that this sequel is a very different breed than its predecessor. The new film does contain fantastic fights, larger and more varied in size and scope, and yes it does contain a rather irresistible vehicular chase that’s refreshingly grounded in realistic physics like the rest of the film. However, the similarities between the two films pretty much end there.After about fifteen minutes into the sequel, you can very much tell that Berandal’s script was originally written for a narrative entirely unrelated to the first Raid and then later retrofitted to bridge as a sequel. The sequel promptly eliminates or ignores every surviving character from the first film besides Rama (lead man Iko Uwais) before the half hour mark (spoilers, including someone who played a very significant and memorable part in the first movie!), and everything from there on out is very different in style from The Raid’s narrative. Where as the original Raid was lean, mean, and all muscle and no fat with a cut-down, minimalist narrative designed solely to serve the action, this Raid 2 is vast, epic, and sprawling. Here, Berandal’s story serves its action, but the reverse is also true. Evans’ sequel has a narrative that matters and plays an intricate part in the film’s overall success, because what’s present is a project that exists to do more than experiment with the limits of cinematic ultraviolence. While The Raid was truly a purebred action film through and through, Berandal is more properly described as a gangster crime drama/action hybrid. It is an entirely different beast.Taking cues from many gangster classics, including Andrew Lau’s and Martin Scorcese’s Infernal Affairs (2002) and The Departed (2006) as well as Francis Ford Coppola’s first two Godfather films (1972, 1974), The Raid 2: Berandal features an ensemble cast with various warring criminal clans jockeying for power in Jarkata’s mean streets. There is a strong undercover element, gangster family rivalry and ambition, and plenty of backstabbing to flesh out and complement the bone-breaking action that everyone’s showing up for to see in the sequel.So, in other words, if you’re coming into this film expecting another minimalist Raid like I unintentionally did when I first went to the theatres, you might be disappointed. If that’s all you want — no risks, just a rehash of the original — you will probably not get what you want with The Raid 2.If however, you’re willing to pay the moderate amount of attention that most crime dramas require in order to follow the plot and all the various players in this story that actually matters this time around, I’m willing to bet you’ll really enjoy this movie.Probably the best thing about Berandal that nobody will expect is how competent the narrative, performances, and character drama actually are. As badass as he was in the original, we never really got to see Uwais act as the hero-cop Rama. We never got to explore him as an actual character and care much about his fate beyond the sheer primal nature of the fights and the fact that Rama seemed like a nice guy with a baby on the way. Here in the sequel, Uwais steps up to the plate and turns in an admirable performance as the lead. Yes he’s an outstanding athlete and choreographer, but this time around he’s also an interesting character worth rooting for. He’s sympathetic, realistic, and even a little cheeky sometimes. His on-screen chemistry with the other actors is great. Uwais may just be one of the few athletes-turned-actors that can in fact, well, act.Speaking of those other actors, the supporting roles turned in by actors Arifin Putra, Alex Abbad, and the rest of the cast are also good. None are out-of-this-world good or truly Academy Award-winning, but by golly all the films’ performances by its whole cast are better than average and help draw you into the characters. For a film that’s drawn so much attention for its violent action scenes, I think that most people are overlooking or forgetting the movies’ acting display. Putra is particularly fun as the ambitious, hothead gangster son, Uco, who is like a bizarre combination of Sonny and Fredo Corleone from The Godfather movies. Uco is short-tempered, violent, and overly self-sensitive with a distinctive inferiority complex. His arc is well written and his role is a big reason why the movie’s story is interesting. Abbad is also interesting for an entirely different reason as Bejo, another young, up-and-coming gangster: He’s a malevolent, calculating villain who’s great fun to hate. Although Tama, the ganglord from the original Raid, was well played by the equally overlooked Ray Sahetapy, he didn’t play much of a direct part in the plot or pose a direct conflict with Rama’s protagonist. Here in Berandal, Abbad poses a direct antagonistic threat to Rama, who has a personal vendetta against Bejo, and has a team of colorful assassins that make him a legitimate threat. By the time the story gets to the halfway mark, you really wanna see Rama kick Bejo’s ass. That sort of emotional animosity just wasn’t in the original Raid.All these various screenplay elements give the sequel a distinct personality and sense of humor that original didn’t have either. The emotional intensity of the action is higher, and parts of the film are quite humorous, such as a scene in a porn factory with a naked women wearing a strap-on, or an assassin playing an impromptu game of baseball with his victims, or some nonchalant sign-language between the aforementioned assassin and his double hammer-wielding sister, or even how a kitchen full of cooks file out of the room with such bored expressions on their faces to let Iko and a boss square off. These are little things that add up, giving personality and charisma to Berandal. They add to the greater narrative and martial arts mayhem taking place, making the movie feel fuller as a result.You’ve probably noticed that I’ve been talking entirely about the characters, performances, and narrative so far — the non-action parts. That’s because, in my opinion, these elements of the movie are important this time around, and more to the point, they matter in a positive way. Berandal is an expansive, sprawling, plot-heavy crime drama that depends to a large extent on its writing beyond the pacing of its action scenes, unlike The Raid. I’ve noticed many critics either criticizing the sequel’s plot for being overly long or too complicated or simply suggesting to ignore the “generic” story altogether and watch the movie simply for the violence. I strongly disagree. Although the film’s conclusion is a bit too rushed and disorganized like Oldboy’s (2003) or The Godfather Part III‘s (1990) endings, for the most part The Raid 2′s screenplay is solid. I don’t understand at all why so many people are complaining about the film being too long or how the plot was too hard to follow. I mean, what do you want the film to do, spoon feed you every single plot piece? The movie is a ensemble gangster piece (with distinct action elements), and it requires that you pay attention to the story to understand what is going on. It is no more complicated than your average Goodfellas (1990), Departed, or Godfather. Ladies and gentlemen, if you can’t follow this movie’s story, than I’m afraid there’s little hope for you following most any film narrative at all.No, Evans really surprised me with his screenplay this time around. While I am a bit disappointed he didn’t better utilize the surviving characters from the first Raid or make better use of the Japanese Goto gang (they mostly just serve as indirect plot devices), I really can’t say that I have much to complain about the movie’s screenplay. The performances and character developments work well together, particularly for Uwais and Putra. All the various plot lines and minor characters work well to flesh out the story, and consequently there isn’t very much filler. If you think otherwise then I’m afraid you just weren’t paying attention. I think what’s really the problem is that, again, people were walking into this movie expecting another Raid exactly like the first one. They just wanted another pure action experience with none of those talking parts. What they got was something very different, but I would argue just as good. The Raid 2: Berandal is every bit as good a film as the first one, but in a very different way.As for the action itself, it is expectedly superb. The hand-to-hand combat is as brutal, visceral, and intense as always. The fights are much more varied this time around, sometimes with dozens of attackers fighting one opponent, sometimes with multiple parties battling en masse, there’s the aforementioned car-chase, and of course the “boss battles.” Guns are used a bit more sparingly than I would’ve liked given the gang war premise, and simply for variety’s sake I expected Evans to take more advantage of his obvious skills shooting gunplay, but there’s enough lead-infused action to suffice. Arguably the greatest thing about the martial arts violence in this movie is that sometimes the good guys actually lose. Rama gets his ass handed to him a couple of times, including to the film’s main boss (one of Abbad’s assassins/bodyguards), and this element of hero vulnerability makes the battles more interesting. Yes, the bad guys often tend to wait their turn to get clobbered rather than just attack all at once, but in the movie’s defense (A) Evans’ cinematography does a great job of shooting the action so he keeps the other attackers out of frame (B) there are instances where the bad guys do rush the lone gunman, and (C) any action fan who’s worth their salt has been accepting this fact as an acceptable level of suspension of disbelief since the days of Bruce Lee. It goes without saying that the action is shot in a way that both respects the choreography and engages the viewer in the intensity of the violence. There is no shaky cam or hyper-editing, wires, or overused CGI here. Uwais and costar/co-choreographer Yayan Ruhian combine their impeccable ability to orchestrate pencak silat brutality with Evans’ eye for cinematic detail and editing precision. The result is pure action brilliance.Finally, the film’s more open and diverse settings allow the camerawork to swoop in and out of the action to give the battles a free-flowing feeling that wasn’t present in the prequel. The different color schemes also make the action scenes more visually diverse and set the tone for each encounter. This is in further stark contrast with the original’s drab, monocolored palette of grey and greyish black. Evans made a deliberate attempt to improve upon the visual quality of the action and it shows.Really, the only area that I would knock the movie on is its pacing in its final half hour. Rama’s vengeful rampage goes on for too long without substantial breaks in the pacing to let the audience rest. Evans gives us three fights more or less back to back to back, with the excitement peaking by the end of the second. This leaves us a little too exhausted to fully enjoy the brilliantly choreographed and shot showdown between Rama and one of Abbad’s assassins (Cecep Arif Rahman) in a kitchen. This misstep in pacing is uncharacteristic of Evans, but I guess the man had to make a mistake with the script’s rhythm sooner or later. If anything the final act should have been stretched out to include more breaks in the action and more fully flesh out the final confrontation between all the murderous gangsters. Oh well.So altogether, Berandal is every bit as good a film as its predecessor, but not for the same exact reasons. I guess I’m still a little disappointed that it isn’t better than the original given how we audiences always want bigger, better, more, more, more…but at the end of the day, the sequel lives up to the hype and is an awesome movie. Evans could’ve made some adjustments here and there, yes, yet he still managed to deliver on a fantastic project by taking advantage of a larger (yet still incredibly small by Hollywood blockbuster standards) budget and doing the gutsy move of expanding upon the source material. The man was simply not content to rehash the first Raid and play it safe. His retrofitting of an older script may make The Raid 2 a sequel only in the loosest sense of the term, but who cares if the movie is of this high quality? The action is impeccable, the story is good, and now I actually feel emotionally invested in Uwais’ character’s survival. The film is more than just a visceral exercise in action filmmaking, acting beyond the pure physicality of its predecessor. This new Raid has a personality and takes its time showing it to you.I for one applaud Evans for doing something different and taking his action franchise in a new direction. The decision has paid off in dividends.I still hold a special place in my heart for the original Raid I saw in 2012. I thought it was one of the best action films I’ve ever seen and I still believe that. It had a pureness and focus to it that made it unique. However, this new Raid film is also special, but in an entirely different way. It is a remarkable hybrid of two of the most entertaining, exciting genres in filmmaking. It wows and excites in a way that only viewers with zero appreciation for either genre will walk away unimpressed.Perhaps the greatest link between The Raid and The Raid 2 is not Rama’s character but the fact that both films talk the talk and walk the walk. They are impeccable, valuable examples of efficient, effective filmmaking done on chump budgets, showing up films funded with resources hundreds of times their size. Unlike the over-CGIed superhero movies, geriatrics with guns, over-CGIed adventure schlock, or shaky cam action flicks in Hollywood or the cartoony, pretentious martial arts flicks from East Asian industries, these Raid films bring the noise. If you’re ready to see hard-hitting cinema that goes for the throat without any apologies, you should watch these films. All other fans too fragile and timid and too used to sanitized, water-down filmmaking, the door’s over there.———————————————————————————————————————————————————–SCORE: 9/10+ Evans mixes epic, juicy gangster drama with hardcore criminal violence and martial arts technique to create a brilliant hybrid of a cinematic experience. Evans’ solid screenplay and amazing direction bring this film together like few filmmakers have ever done before in either the action or the crime drama genres. The film has both personality and visual style to match Evans’ ambition.+ Uwais and Ruhian deliver once again with amazing choreography that goes beyond spectacle and morphs into an art form as intricate, primal, and beautiful as the lushest, most passionate Bollywood dance ensemble. The film’s action sequences are a bloody, brutal ballet.+ Uwais proves he has dramatic muscle to back up his ass-kicking abilities, becoming both a sympathetic and likable character center that holds the narrative together. The rest of the cast do admirable jobs supporting the story, particularly Putra and Abbad as the angst-ridden gangster prince and conniving villain respectively.- Evans does become a bit overzealous by the film’s end, packing in three big fights in a row when he should’ve given the audience some time to rest in between. The Japanese Yakuza element doesn’t come into play much despite some implications in the screenplay. Ruhian’s character’s hair and makeup look totally ridiculous and make you laugh at the movie in one awkward scene.? [Back in 2012] — Do you have a title for the sequel?[Gareth Evans] — It’s called Berandal, but we’re gonna change that, we gotta find something else. I’m hoping not “The Raid 2″…
summary: A Potent, Visceral Genre Hybrid of Crime and Action: If all you want is a rehash of the original, walk away now....

reviewText: The Raid: Redemption was one of my favorite martial arts films of the past decade.  It was the film that likely introduced many of us to the Indonesian martial art style known as pencak silat and star Iko Uwais.  Uwais reprises his role Indonesian cop Rama who barely survived a SWAT team raid on the high rise building of a ruthless gang lord.  The Raid 2 picks up right where the first film left off.  Rama is offered a position with a clandestine unit in the police department which targets corrupt cops including Commissioner Reza.Rama goes undercover in a prison where he befriends Uco, the son of one of Jakarta’s most powerful organized crime bosses.  Once out of prison Rama meets Uco’s father Bangun and is accepted into the family.  Uco becomes frustrated at not having a more important role in the organization and his father’s reluctance to go to war with a rival Japanese organization.  Uco hatches a plot with Bejo, a young, rising gang lord to start a war between his Uco’s family and the Japanese.  The pair plans to take control of all organized crime once the dust settles from the war, eliminating Commissioner Reza in the process.  Rama finds himself caught up in the web of plots, trying to keep his alias a secret while trying to stop the impending war.The Raid 2 is a very different film from the first but also quite exceptional.  The first film was limited to the claustrophobic floors and rooms of the rundown apartment building.  That film was an endurance test as Rama had to battle through legions of thugs, floor by grueling floor.  The Raid 2 is a more complex film and more wide open.  If it has a fault it is that its plot is too think and laden with so many characters it’s hard to keep track of them all.  You have three different crime families, to go along with the good cops, the bad cops, and other stray characters that walk in and out of the production, many adding little to the story.But these are not films you watch for logical narratives.  You watch them for the edge-of-your-seat action sequences and The Raid 2 doesn’t disappoint.  Iko Uwais’ unique fighting style produces some of the best close combat fighting sequences you’ve ever seen.  As in the first he particularly shines when confined to cramped spaces like the stall of men’s room as he has to fight off a score of inmates.  There are few martial arts stars in the world the can match him for pure dynamic fighting sequences.This time however Uwais is able to add foot chases and a truly unique car chase/shootout to the action repertoire.  The Raid 2, again like the first, is off the charts in terms of its sheer brutality.  Rama’s fight with the appropriately named “Baseball Bat Man” and “Hammer Girl” is particularly bloody.  Rama may be the hero but he endures nearly as much punishment as he doles out.  This is Director Gareth Evans’ third teaming with Uwais and they have developed perfect chemistry.  While it may lack the first film’s straight forward and frenetic pace, The Raid 2 is a flawed but thrilling sequel.
summary: Redemption was one of my favorite martial arts films of the past decade
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yesterday, I happened to catch one of the finest and most bone-crunching, pain-and-injury dwelling action films since Rambo IV. That film is known as The Raid 2. Booooo!Without going too long into what I will be saying, The Raid 2 is a fine accomplishment and a sequel to an already great and strongly-paced film. The sequel finds our hero and survivor from the last film, Rama (Iko Uwais), now becoming an undercover cop and a pawn for a wealthy yet corrupt crime syndicate in Jakarta. His aim and efforts are to witness their actions and clamp down on the illegal activities, bribery, and violence.The Raid 2 is very much like a crime thriller-cum-action/martial arts film that often feels more like a Michael Mann film like "Heat" or John Woo's "Hard Boiled" or "The Killer" than something like "Ong-Bak" or even "Die Hard."The action, which was noted on several sources, as being one of the most violent ever elaborated and choreographed on screen is tough-as-nails, hardcore, and very bloody. The film had to be trimmed slightly to get an R rating instead of an NC-17 just confirms the audience how much blood and guts you can expect. It makes Kill Bill: Vol. 1 look amateur. Tarantino, watch out.Aside from "just" the action, the storyline has improved and is more refined to add more complexity about corruption and criminal business, the budget feels like $70 million but from research was made for about $4.5 million as Indonesia does not do labour unions and such, the 2 hour, 30 minute running time did not feel wasted but it did feel indulgent in a good way, the universe of The Raid feels a lot more expansive and gritty, and the film ends on a note that does not feel like a cliffhanger which was my main concern about the film.The film's few downfalls or discrepancies might have to do with the strange usage of English in a few scenes, the realization that the version I saw in America was not entirely "uncut" but trimmed (but still, nonetheless, very violent, brutal, and bloody), and the expansive universe just did not have the same grip or "awe" factor that I had when I first saw the first film with no or little expectations.For the uninitiated, this is a hard sell not just because it is foreign but because it ties previous information and twists genre tropes to create a more dense and dramatic crime action thriller. Still, for fans, this is a sure-fire treat for the eyes and for the gut. The Raid 2 is one of the most, in youth-speak, "ballsiest" action films to come around and given its history and international cooperation as an Indonesian production with some Japanese and the creation coming from a Welsh filmmaker, this is surely a case of intrigue and amazement.The Raid 2, while not The Raid, is still a highly commendable effort and I URGE you to see this over-the-top and at-your-face  actioner over PG-13 soft actioners like Captain America or even Hollywood nonsense like The Expendables.
summary: A film with nails on every part of its body. Solid, violent, over-the-top entertainment. For fans of Michael Mann or John Woo.

reviewText: This is not a DVD or Blu-ray review. This is a review of the movie itself watching this on Amazon instant video. The 2.5 stars or rather 3 stars rounded up is in comparison to the first movie. The first movie being a 5 star. As a big fan of the first movie I was really looking forward to watching the Raid 2! Unfortunately, The Raid 2 doesn't quite live up to the charm of the first and here is why. The story in the original Raid was very straightforward, simplistic, and easy to follow playing out like a video game with sub bosses along the way. In the sequel much more emphasizes was placed on creating a much more complex story and unfortunately that's where The Raid 2 fails. The Raid 2 story is a convoluted mess that left me clueless as to what was taking place and why. Something to do with some cops gone rogue I think. What's worse is that no real explanations was given as to whom most of these characters were in the movie or why they were there to begin with. This movie had a lady with hammers. A guy with a baseball bat. A major sub boss character killed off in the first movie playing a somewhat different role in this movie sort of. Crime bosses whom I didn't know whether to feel sorry for or happy that they were finally killed off, etc.. To Raid 2 credit, The Raid 2 does bring back some of the classic fights and death kills present in the original. The saving grace of this movie. Ironically, even the fights and death kills present in the Raid 2 doesn't quite live up to the brutality of the original Raid.
